SUMMARY: BluR is a MerR-like regulator that contains an N-terminal helix-turn-helix DNA-binding region and a ligand-binding region in C-terminal domain [12829265]. BluR functions as a repressor for genes involved in modulation of biofilm formation and for acid resistance genes [19240136]. Its expression is strongly induced at low temperatures [19240136, 19011022, 18174134]. BluR is a paralogue of MlrA, and it represses transcription of ycgZ-ymgA-ariR-ymgC operon [19240136, 22783906]. This operon is transcribed divergently on opposite strand, under control of Ïƒ38 (RpoS) RNA polymerase [19240136, 18158297]. Its gene products are involved in production of colanic acid, a component of biofilm matrix, via Rcs phosphorelay system [17222132, 17609140, 17765265, 19172264]. bluRF-ycgZ-ymgA-ariR region is conserved in various enteric bacteria [19240136, 22783906]. BluR binds to promoter region of ycgZ. BluF is an antagonist of BluR [19240136, 22783906]. It binds to N-terminal domain of BluR and inhibits DNA-binding activity of BluR. Binding of BluF to BluR is stimulated by blue light [19240136, 22783906]. Although bluR and bluF are transcribed in same direction and located next to each or on chromosome, y do not constitute an operon [19240136].
